channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Get your foot in the door! UK Remote Jr. Perl Developer
item.description: We know that a lack of commercial experience doesn’t always reflect skill level, know-how, or programming brilliance. You know your stuff. You’re keen to grow and learn. You know that if someone would only just give you a chance, and let you in the door, you could really shine!

item.title: Can’t find the right job? Build your own! Remote Perl role in Australia
item.description: If you’re a senior Perl developer — you’ve already got the most important component of what our client is looking for. Other important bits: in an ideal world, you’ll have experience with most or all of Catalyst, REST, Dancer2, Moo, DBlx::Class, MySQL, Postgres, and docker. Want to add extra flair? AngularJS or Vue would take you to the next level.

item.title: Perl Superheroes Wanted! Remote Perl within US time zone
item.description: Does your boss treat you like a Perl superhero? If the answer is no, we’ve got a role open that’ll inspire you to leap a tall building with excitement. Best of all, this position is 100% remote within the USA. Our client is looking for a Perl developer with Catalyst and DBlx::Class, and you should have a few solid years of commercial experience under your Batman utility belt.

item.title: Cruise into this Dreamy Career. Perl role in Malta
item.description: Our client is an international company who pride themselves on making online trading a breeze. After twenty-plus years cruising the financial waters, they’re subject matter experts who provide a stable, engaging environment for their crew. Located in glorious Malta, they offer a supportive team that believes in open communication and solving problems together.

item.title: Looking Boss! 100% remote Perl role within UK & EU
item.description: Our client is looking for a full-stack Perl developer who takes autonomy to a new level. You’ll work like the business is your own because you’re the kind of person who takes pride in what they produce, and you’ll welcome the chance to dabble in multiple roles because you like to keep it fresh.

item.title: Boston Perl Mongers Online Meeting - topic TBD
item.description: Tuesday February 8th, 2021 07:00 PM Eastern Time (US and Canada)

item.title: Developing a caching plugin for LWP::UserAgent and HTTP::Tiny
item.description: Wednesday, January 26, 2022; 06:00 PM Eastern Time (US and Canada)

item.title: LibreLingo development with the author
item.description: In this video you see a long pair programming session with Dániel Kántor and Gábor Szabó making some changes to the LibreLingo project. Front-end: Svelte and Bulma. Testing with Cypress.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge 148: Eban, Cardano
item.description: A very unique solution to Eban numbers task. I loved it. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Numbers in words and Cardano triplets
item.description: Peter choose to discuss Cardano Triplets solution. Thanks for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 148
item.description: Cardano Triplets solution as one-liner in Perl is really cool. Amazing work, keep it up.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 148: eban vs cardano
item.description: Thanks Luca for sharing Raku almost equality operator. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 148: Eban Numbers and Cardano Triplets
item.description: Laurent shared one-liner in Raku to solve Eban numbers task. Really cool, thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #148
item.description: James is known for compact solution. This week too he shared very cool solutions. You don't want to miss it.

item.title: PWC148 - Cardano Triplets
item.description: Flavio lazy solution to Cardano Triplets is still very cool. Thanks for your contributions as always.

item.title: PWC148 - Eban Numbers
item.description: Flavio shared two flavours this week, and that too in Perl and Raku both. Keep it up great work.

item.title: It's Triplets!: Weekly Challenge #148
item.description: Dave's blog shared an interesting fact about cube root of a negative number. Thanks for the concise and to the point blog.

item.title: Eban Cardano the Third with Raku and Perl
item.description: Arne being Raku expert, I would like to thank him for introducing Math::BigInt::Named to me. Plenty to learn every week from his blog. Thanks for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 148: Cardano Triplets
item.description: Abigail going into detailed mathematical operation behind the task. Exceptional derivation. You don't want to skip it.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 148: Eban Numbers
item.description: Abigail is master of Perl one-liner using regex. I loved the task analysis, eye-opener for me. Thanks for sharing the knowledge as always.

item.title: Perl Review - Perl Weekly Challenge - 144
item.description: Perl Solutions Review by Colin Crain.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 148
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Eban Numbers" and "Cardano Triplets" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 149
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Fibonacci Digit Sum" and "Largest Square". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Paste around
item.description: Ever wanted to share code, then this is your friend.

item.title: My Favorite Warnings: qw
item.description: Tom shares more information about one of the most commonly used qw() construct.

item.title: Get out early with Perl statement modifiers
item.description: Yet another cool blog by Mark for you if you want to explore different ways to exit early using Perl.

item.title: Data::Tubes release and... how cool is CPAN Testers?!?
item.description: Find out more about the recent release of Data::Tubes by Flavio.

item.title: App::Easer guides
item.description: Thanks to Flavio for sharing tutorials of App::Easer.

item.title: Call for Papers, Perl & Raku Conference in Houston 2022
item.description: The Perl & Raku Conference is a high-quality, inexpensive, technical Conference that celebrates the family of Perl programming languages. Do submit papers if you are keen to give talk.

item.title: Git::Critic
item.description: Do you like Perl::Critic but you can't use it against your legacy codebase because it reports too many problems? Then you should try this new module and share your experience with the author.

item.title: RFC-Modern OOP In Perl
item.description: It's official, Corinna is going to the Perl core, most probably after the release of 5.36.

item.title: #548 - Perl Books Collection
item.description:
Hi there

Do you have Perl books collection?

I am sure most of us, do own the Camel book. As we know, there are hardly any new Perl book published in recent years. I recently bought two very popular Perl books "Extending and Embedding Perl" and "Network Programming with Perl". I realised there are two distinct views about good old Perl books. One view is that the recommendations in these books are no longer in use, since we have better choices available on CPAN now. I fully agree to this view but I also agree to the other view that it is still relevant in terms of base knowledge of the subject. Above all, there is a sentimental values attached to each Perl book that I own.

How about you?

Last week, Gabor, spoke about learning language in the editorial. Being, an Indian by birth, I know more than just the national language of India, Hindi. I can understand, to be precise, 6 human languages. Now a days, I am learning Spanish from my daughter as she is learning part of her school curriculum. But here I would like to know how many programming languages one can fluently code in. Recently in The Weekly Challenge contest, we have received loads of solutions in different languages. In the week 147, we received 100+ solutions. One member stands out in the crowd is, Abigail, who have contributed in 30 different programming languages. To me, it is impossible but he did it.

How many programming languages I know? Well thanks to the weekly challenge, I got the opportunity to code in Raku, Python, Java and Swift as well as Perl, ofcourse. Do you want to try some new language, please give it a try.

Enjoy the week and stay safe.
